awd_titl_txt: EAGER:  DynaMo:  A novel computational workflow for dynamic monographs and revisionary systematics
awd_abstract_narration:
Taxonomic monographs combine information about the appearance, occurrence, genealogical relationships, and classification of organisms and provide methods for their identification.  This baseline information is critical for understanding the diversity of life and helps inform other biological research questions.  Current taxonomic monographs suffer from being static documents that do not provide an efficient means of accessing or analyzing the underlying data. This project will develop a linked set of computational tools (DynaMo) to produce a dynamic monograph that streamlines the workflow, integrates specimen-based data, and facilitates analysis of these data. Despite being in the early stages of development DynaMo shows immense potential to transform how taxonomic monographs are generated, analyzed and presented. The project will train a post-doctoral researcher and undergraduates, including members of underrepresented groups, in systematic biology, bioinformatics, and software development.  Two workshops on dynamic monographs and quantitative taxonomy will help train the broader systematics community. The resulting DynaMo software, and all data generated by the project, will be made freely available through public databases and repositories.

While other areas of systematics have adopted modern approaches, the production of taxonomic monographs has been hindered by the lack of efficient computational tools to efficiently integrate and update the large data sets and complex analyses that underly monographic research. This project will develop the digital infrastructure (DynaMo) to enable systematists to document and interact with all the data management and analysis tools needed to produce a monograph and help make monographic methods and analyses more transparent, reproducible, and extendable. The digital infrastructure underpinning this workflow will be a generic relational database that stores all primary biodiversity data as well as intermediate resources for faster retrieval. The data stored in the database will be integrated and analyzed via modular pipelines. This database will be continuously updated as new data and results become available and the analysis pipelines will automatically generate new results whenever the underlying data in the database change. The results of analyses, interactive visualizations, raw data, and text will be machine-readable and accessible via a dynamic monograph, an online document that is perpetually up-to-date because it provides an interface to the underlying specimen-based database.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching ​goal of this project was to develop a new computational framework to integrate data for revisionary systematics and build dynamic documents, which would work as dynamic taxonomic monographs. Taxonomic monographs are synthetic documents that centralize primary biodiversity data about specific organismal groups, and provide the very foundation of comparative biology​. Writing a taxonomic monograph, however, is complicated because it requires the assembly, acquisition, analysis, synthesis, and interpretation of diverse types of data associated with museum specimens. Over the years, there have been significant advances in methods and tools that facilitate the individual components of a monograph, such as the development of statistical approaches to study character variation, explicit methods to delimit species, powerful geographic information systems, robust approaches for phylogenetic inference, and comprehensive nomenclatural databases, among others. However, building a monograph is not just a matter of executing available tools for each of these components. It requires compiling all these data in a usable format, integrating it, and sharing all this underlying information with the scientific community in a standard format to make taxonomy explicit, testable, and reproducible. In addition to these challenges, detailed records must be tracked for each specimen, data files require different formats, analyses need to be explicit, and the final results must be flexible enough to facilitate connectivity with other analyses which rely on taxonomic information. Taken together, this poses at least three potential complications for modern monographic research. First, systematists have to spend significantly more time in “data wrangling” rather than in data interpretation and inference. Second, monographs are difficult to implement and explicitly describe, making it hard to evaluate results, integrate data across studies, expand analyses, or test the impact of alternative analyses. Third, monographs published as paper-based documents are “static documents” which get out of date almost immediately as new methods and data become available. The central aim of this project was to address these limitations by developing a computational framework to integrate the rich specimen-based data and analyses that make up a monograph, hence increasing the visibility and impact of taxonomy. To accomplish this goal, this project completed two specific aims. First, we designed and implemented a relational database to store information derived from museum specimens, and second, harnessing the power of virtual tables (a piece of code that supports SQL operations) we used this approach to run and re-run analyses on the fly to generate a final or alternative output based on particular analysis pipelines. The advantage of using virtual tables is that only raw data needs to be stored in the database without the need to store specific results because these can change given different queries. To achieve this, we developed a set of default analysis pipelines for taxonomy using the R and C languages, which interact with our SQLite database and which can be expanded and linked to other pipelines downstream facilitating the connectivity of taxonomy with other analyses. To generate modern dynamic monographs, we propose to use the collaborative canvas Observable, which uses all industry standards for science reproducibility. 

In the process of generating the new computational framework for taxonomy and systematics, we also modified one of the algorithms we are using for species delimitation and proposed a new algorithm to study heterogeneity in the rate of evolution of phenotypic traits. This manuscript was published in the journal Systematic Biology. In addition, we used our database of genomic, phenotypic, and spatial data for a group of Andean plants to re-assess the taxonomic species proposed for these plants discovering that taxonomy is a poor surrogate of biological species. This manuscript was published in the journal Scientific Reports.

This project supported the professional development of one postdoctoral researcher and one undergraduate student (underrepresented minority in STEM). The postdoctoral scholar secured a subsequent postdoctoral position and the undergraduate student is now a researcher in a Natural History Museum. All the code used to generate our results and pipelines is shared publicly enabling other researchers to reproduce and expand our work. The impact of the publications resulting from this project have the potential to reach areas outside of systematic biology. For instance, the publication about the method to study the tempo and mode of evolution will contribute to major efforts to understanding the evolution of traits across the tree of life given the speed and accuracy of our proposed approach. In addition, our standardization to store  specimen-based data and metadata has the potential to influence the development of novel machine learning/artificial intelligence technologies to extract, sort and analyze biodiversity data.
